channel.title: Python Noob
channel.description:
Yep yep, that is me :) Just started learning it (a few hours ago), and so far it seems like quite a neat language and with all the toolkits available. It looks quite useful for a gnome user (with pyGtk, although I'm sure there are Qt, Clutter, ect.. bindings too for other window managers).
Anywho, here is my first program :) I pretty much always do calculator scripts first hah, not quite sure why. [code] operation = raw_input('Choose your operation (a, s, m, d): ')
if operation != 'a' and operation != 's' and operation != 'm' and operation != 'd': print ('\nQuitting program: Invalid Operation...') raise SystemExit
numberOne = raw_input('Choose your first number: ') numberTwo = raw_input('Choose your second number: ')
numberOne = int(numberOne) numberTwo = int(numberTwo)
if operation == 'a': total = numberOne + numberTwo strOperation = "Added" symOperation = "+"
if operation == 's': total = numberOne - numberTwo strOperation = "Subtracted" symOperation = "-"
if operation == 'm': total = numberOne * numberTwo strOperation = "Multiplied" symOperation = "*"
if operation == 'd': total = numberOne / numberTwo strOperation = "Divided" symOperation = "/"
print ('\n**********************\n') print ('Operation: ' + strOperation + '\n') print (str(numberOne) + ' ' + symOperation + ' ' + str(numberTwo)) print ('> ' + str(total) + ' <') print ('\n**********************') [/code]
Is anyone here familiar with the pyGtk bindings? If so, please hit me up. I feel like some examples in action would be really really beneficial.
Thanks a ton ~Dave
EDIT: I suppose thats something like what you meant? It is a very neat concept that I haven't seen outside of python. [code] #Create dictonary d = {"a":"Addition", "s":"Subtraction", "m":"Multiplication", "d":"Division", "operation":"0", "work":"0"}
#Request operation d["operation"] = raw_input('>> Choose your operation (a, s, m, d): ')
#Filter if d["operation"] != 'a' and d["operation"] != 's' and d["operation"] != 'm' and d["operation"] != 'd': print ('\nQuitting program: Invalid Operation...') raise SystemExit
#Request Numbers numberOne = raw_input('>> Choose your first number: ') numberTwo = raw_input('>> Choose your second number: ')
#Cases if d["operation"] == 'a': total = int(numberOne) + int(numberTwo) d["work"] = numberOne + " + " + numberTwo + " = " + str(total)
if d["operation"] == 's': total = int(numberOne) - int(numberTwo) d["work"] = numberOne + " - " + numberTwo + " = " + str(total)
if d["operation"] == 'm': total = int(numberOne) * int(numberTwo) d["work"] = numberOne + " * " + numberTwo + " = " + str(total)
if d["operation"] == 'd': total = int(numberOne) / int(numberTwo) d["work"] = numberOne + " / " + numberTwo + " = " + str(total)
#Print Output print ('\n**********************\n') print "> " + d["work"] + " <"; print ('\n**********************') [/code]

item.title: Python Noob
item.dc:creator: @Evil1 Evil_
item.description:

x = raw_input("Enter the expression (e.g. (2+2) * 15 - 23 + (21 / 3)): ")

print "Result: %s" % str(eval(x))

[/quote]

item.title: Python Noob
item.dc:creator: @oblivian oblivian
item.description:
@oblivian wrote:

Ahh I think something like

def add(a, b):
    return a + b;
def sub(a, b):
    return a - b;
def mul(a, b):
    return a * b;
def div(a, b):
    return a / b;

d = {"a": add, "s": sub, "m": mul, "d": div}

numberOne = int(raw_input("Number one:   "))
numberTwo = int(raw_input("Number two:   "))

try:
    total = (d[raw_input("What op you want? (a, s, m, d):   ")](numberOne, numberTwo))
except LookupError:
    print "\n Invalid entry. Exiting now..."
    raise SystemExit

print "**************\n"
print ">> ", total, " <<"
print "\n**************"

looks a little cleaner (as opposed to using lamba) Anywho, sorry for being a dumbass. And many thanks especially to abraham2119

Read full topic

yea wutever works

item.title: Python Noob
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

aha nice attempt but it can be so much more efficient…

def Add(a, b):
    return a + b;
def Sub(a, b):
    return a - b;
def Mul(a, b):
    return a * b;
def Div(a, b):
    return a / b;

operations = { "a" : Add, "s" : Sub, "m" : Mul, "d" : Div  }

op = raw_input('>> Choose your operation (a, s, m, d):   ')
if not operations.has_key(op):
    print ('\nQuitting program: Invalid Operation...')
    raise SystemExit
a = int(raw_input('>> Choose your first number:   '))
b = int(raw_input('>> Choose your second number:   '))

print ('\n**********************\n')
print ">  " + str(operations[op](a, b)) + "  <";
print ('\n**********************')

Read full topic

item.title: Python Noob
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

I’m not familiar with pyGtk, but as for you application, a more elegant approach would have been to have a dictionary of associative “character:function” types and then just have done “<dictionary_instance>raw_input(…)”.

Read full topic

item.title: Python Noob
item.dc:creator: @oblivian oblivian
item.description:
@oblivian wrote:

Yep yep, that is me Just started learning it (a few hours ago), and so far it seems like quite a neat language and with all the toolkits available. It looks quite useful for a gnome user (with pyGtk, although I’m sure there are Qt, Clutter, ect… bindings too for other window managers).

Anywho, here is my first program I pretty much always do calculator scripts first hah, not quite sure why.

operation = raw_input('Choose your operation (a, s, m, d):   ')

if operation != 'a' and operation != 's' and operation != 'm' and operation != 'd':
  print ('\nQuitting program: Invalid Operation...')
  raise SystemExit

numberOne = raw_input('Choose your first number:   ')
numberTwo = raw_input('Choose your second number:   ')

numberOne = int(numberOne)
numberTwo = int(numberTwo)


if operation == 'a':
  total = numberOne + numberTwo
  strOperation = "Added"
  symOperation = "+"

if operation == 's':
  total = numberOne - numberTwo
  strOperation = "Subtracted"
  symOperation = "-"

if operation == 'm':
  total = numberOne * numberTwo
  strOperation = "Multiplied"
  symOperation = "*"

if operation == 'd':
  total = numberOne / numberTwo
  strOperation = "Divided"
  symOperation = "/"


print ('\n**********************\n')
print ('Operation: ' + strOperation + '\n')
print (str(numberOne) + ' ' + symOperation + ' ' + str(numberTwo))
print ('> ' + str(total) + ' <')
print ('\n**********************')

Is anyone here familiar with the pyGtk bindings? If so, please hit me up. I feel like some examples in action would be really really beneficial.

Thanks a ton
~Dave

EDIT: I suppose thats something like what you meant? It is a very neat concept that I haven’t seen outside of python.

#Create dictonary
d = {"a":"Addition", "s":"Subtraction", "m":"Multiplication", "d":"Division", "operation":"0", "work":"0"}

#Request operation
d["operation"] = raw_input('>> Choose your operation (a, s, m, d):   ')

#Filter
if d["operation"] != 'a' and d["operation"] != 's' and d["operation"] != 'm' and d["operation"] != 'd':
  print ('\nQuitting program: Invalid Operation...')
  raise SystemExit

#Request Numbers
numberOne = raw_input('>> Choose your first number:   ')
numberTwo = raw_input('>> Choose your second number:   ')

#Cases
if d["operation"] == 'a':
  total = int(numberOne) + int(numberTwo)
  d["work"] = numberOne + " + " + numberTwo + " = " + str(total)

if d["operation"] == 's':
  total = int(numberOne) - int(numberTwo)
  d["work"] = numberOne + " - " + numberTwo + " = " + str(total)

if d["operation"] == 'm':
  total = int(numberOne) * int(numberTwo)
  d["work"] = numberOne + " * " + numberTwo + " = " + str(total)

if d["operation"] == 'd':
  total = int(numberOne) / int(numberTwo)
  d["work"] = numberOne + " / " + numberTwo + " = " + str(total)

#Print Output
print ('\n**********************\n')
print ">  " + d["work"] + "  <";
print ('\n**********************')

Read full topic
